resources.string: Obstructive Sleep Apnoea (OSA) occurs when a person repeatedly stops breathing during the night. The lack of oxygen arouses the person from sleep just enough for normal breathing to resume, but this often goes unnoticed by the person themselves (causing tiredness during the day).
What are the symptoms of OSA?

Usually the person will snore, or they will have noisy/laboured breathing interrupted by gasping/snorting each time their breathing resumes. Common symptoms include:

	•	sleepiness during the day
	•	sore/dry throat on awakening
	•	poor memory/concentration
	•	headaches
	•	irritability or short temper
	•	anxiety
	•	depression
	•	reduced libido

OSA is caused by the collapse of the muscles and soft tissue in the back of the throat. This narrows or completely blocks the airway resulting in an interrupted supply of oxygen. The brain recognises this and wakes the person up enough for normal breathing to resume. There are a number of risk factors, including:

	•	being overweight
	•	being male
	•	being over 50
	•	having a large neck
	•	alcohol/sedatives
	•	smoking
	•	family history of OSA
	•	diabetes
	•	nasal congestion

OSA is diagnosed with a full night\'s sleep study. You will either spend a night in hospital or you will be given a kit to take home. Both setups record a variety of physiological signals, and possible a questionnaire. The data will be analysed by a sleep specialist who diagnoses sleep disorders.

Lifestyle changes, such as losing weight, quitting smoking, and avoiding alcohol, can all help in milder cases of OSA. The most common and effective treatment is continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). This involves wearing a mask while asleep in order to keep the airway open. Other treatment options include surgery and dental devices.
How can I minimise the risk of OSA?

Some lifestyle changes can help to minimise the risk of OSA, such as:

	•	losing weight
	•	avoiding alcohol in the evening
	•	quitting smoking
	•	avoiding all sedatives
	•	avoiding sleeping on your back
The following questionnaire is a simple screening tool which assesses your risk of OSA.
Do you often feel tired during the day?
Has anyone seen you stop breathing during sleep?
Do you have high blood pressure?
What is your height and weight?
No recordings have been made. Please record data before analysing.

Oxygen Desaturation Index (ODI) is a measure of how often the amount of oxygen in your blood dips below normal. This happens frequently to OSA patients. An ODI of 5 or above means that you are at high risk of OSA.

The questionnaire is used to screen for obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA). It can be used as a first layer of screening for OSA, but by itself it is not sufficient for any diagnostic purposes. A score of 3 or above means you are at high risk of OSA.
Your risk of having OSA is calculated by a classifier designed to determine whether your sleep data means that you are likely to have OSA or not.
If you wish you can upload your data for it to be analysed remotely. To do so, click \"Perform cloud analysis\" below.
Something\'s gone wrong - please fill in the questionnaire again.
Your answers to the questionnaire indicate that you have a low risk of OSA. You can use this app to record and analyse your sleep to confirm this result if you wish - press \'record\' to begin.

Your answers to the questionnaire indicate that you have a high risk of OSA. You can use this app to record and analyse your sleep to confirm this result (just press \'record\'), or you can consult a sleep lab.
Choose data to use for analysis:
Please ensure you have done the following:
Please check all boxes before continuing.
No recordings have been made. Please record and analyse some data.
Bluetooth has been turned off. Please turn it back on to connect.
Bluetooth has been turned back on. You can now reconnect.
Can\'t find a record of your quesionnaire - please ensure you have completed it.
Below are some examples of breathing during sleep.
Recording has been stopped. Because of this, no analysis is possible and the files will be deleted.
Recording finished successfully. You can now analyse your data.
Place the phone in the armband on your preferred arm. Make sure the phone is facing directly forward as shown in the picture.

Use headphones with a built-in microphone. Plug them into the phone, pull the cable up through your pyjama sleeve, and attach it to your nose using surgical tape or any medical adhesive. Ensure the microphone is placed next to (but not under) the nose as shown. Make sure that the microphone hole is not directed toward your skin.
Attach the pulse oximeter to your preferred wrist. Place your finger (index, middle or ring) in the finger cuff as shown in the picture. Make sure that the cable is on the back of your hand.

• You should not sleep near sources of noise such as TV, radio or open windows
  • It is best to sleep alone
  • Make sure you have enough battery for a full night\'s recording to be taken
  • If you manually stop the recording at any time, you will have to perform the test again
Number of seconds to display when recording.
MAC address of pulse oximeter. Enter the address in the format AA:AA:AA:AA:AA:AA.
Observe 30 min delay before recording begins.
Delete files on early exit from recording.
Require 500MB space and 60% battery to record.
No paired devices. Please restart the recording.
Please charge your phone to at least 60% before recording.
There isn\'t enough space on your phone to store a night\'s recordings. Please make sure there is at least 500MB free.
You are at risk of OSA.
You are not at risk of OSA.
Do you really want to stop recording?

SleepAp version 1.2 (beta). This application is based on ongoing research within the Intelligent Patient Monitoring group, Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford. To report bugs or give us feedback, please send an email to sleepapdev@gmail.com.

Copyright © 2013, University of Oxford. All rights reserved. Software released under the GNU General Public Licence.

NOT MEDICAL SOFTWARE. This software is provided for informational or research purposes only, and is not for professional medical use, diagnosis, treatment or care, nor is it intended to be a substitute therefor. Always seek the advice of a physician or other qualified health provider properly licensed to practice medicine or general healthcare in your jurisdiction concerning any questions you may have regarding any health problem. Never disregard professional medical advice or delay in seeking it because of something you have observed through the use of this software. Always consult with your physician or other qualified health care provider before embarking on a new treatment, diet or fitness programme.

Graphical charts copyright © AndroidPlot, SVM component copyright © LIBSVM - all rights reserved.
Before recording can begin, you must have completed the questionnaire. You can do this from the main menu.

In order to analyse your sleep, the app must record undisturbed sleep. To avoid being disturbed during the night, please put your phone into silent mode - this will happen automatically when the box is ticked.
In order for the pulse oximeter to connect to your device, Bluetooth must be switched on. Please tick the box and follow the on-screen prompts to turn Bluetooth on.

Before the pulse oximeter can send data to your phone, you must first make sure the two devices are \'paired\' - pairing only needs to happen the first time you connect the pulse oximeter. To pair the devices, tick the box and follow the on-screen prompts. If you are asked for a PIN, it should be found on the back of the pulse oximeter.
The data captured during your sleep must be stored on your phone. To ensure there is enough room for the data, please make sure there is at least 500MB of space in your phone\'s storage.
If your phone runs out of battery during the recording, the captured data will be useless. To avoid this happening, please ensure you have enough battery to last the night.
